moves.1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. Bb5+ Bd7 4. Bxd7+: The game starts with a series of sacrifices, and white with a slight development advantage.
moves.6... g6 7. b3 Bg7 8. Bb2: Both players want to capture the opposing rook with their bishops.
moves.8... e6 9. Nxe6: White threatens the queen while revealing the bishop, looking to attack while the queen retreats...
moves.9... Qa5+: ...but the queen forces white to make a defensive move instead.
moves.10. Qd2 Qxd2+ 11. Nxd2 Bxb2: Black gains a tempo, and material.
moves.12. Rb1 Bc3 13. Nc7+: However, the threat to the bishop results in a knight fork, and black loses a rook.
moves.13... Kd8 14. Nxa8 Ngf6 15. f3 d5 16. ex: White is very cramped. He decides to move the rook into play.
moves.20... f6 21. Ra4 Rxa8 22. Ne4 Ne3+ 23. K: A clever move; the knight will be moved to reveal the check from behind. White must move his king out of the way.
moves.25. Rd1+ Kc6 26. Kf2 Nf4 27. Rxf4 Re6 28: White, ahead in material, offers a rook exchange. Black, not wanting to retreat, accepts.
A pointless check; it achieves nothing.
moves.42. Kd3 Nxa2 43. Rxg6+ Ka5 44. Rf6 Nb4+: Possibly the worst move available. It opens the door for the knight fork, Nd5!+
The second pawn is now unstoppable. Faced with the prospect of two queens, Black resigns.
